awd_titl_txt: Compact Phase-Modulated Photonic Structures for On-Chip Multiband Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the rapid developments of highly-integrated photonics and quantum communication technologies as well as the recent advancements of high-resolution medical imaging techniques, there is currently a compelling need for miniaturized and scalable optical elements that enable simultaneous light focusing and directional control over different spectral bands. Responding to these challenges, this project advances the understanding of optical devices that combine multiple functionalities on the nanoscale. The research team utilizes experimental and computational approaches to help develop novel materials and structures that enable controllable light focusing responses with reduced losses and enhanced efficiency for use in next generation of power-efficient nanophotonics devices, such as on-chip spectrometers, optical sensors, and miniaturized imaging systems that operate over multiple and spectral regions. The project supports one graduate student and encourages the involvement of undergraduate students in the research through a vibrant outreach program aimed at introducing fundamental concepts of optical science and engineering in their academic curricula in partnership with practical laboratory demonstrations and research activities through summer programs at Boston University. An important component of this outreach plan is to attract underrepresented minorities to a career in optical engineering through participation in the project. Finally, the outreach involves the development of a focused teaching module addressing the emerging field of Metaphotonics that will be offered to students (graduate and undergraduate) and practitioners both in industry and academia as part of the photonics outreach programs at Boston University.

The primary goal of this proposal is to combine favorable aspects from both meta-optics and diffractive optics technologies in order to design, fabricate, and experimentally characterize high-performance, ultra-compact novel diffractive devices with spatially-modulated phase profiles based on high-index transparent materials and scalable multi-level fabrication. In particular, the researchers will focus on two closely related novel photonic structures: (i) single-element, ultra-compact micro- spectrometers based on achromatic axilenses with engineered phase modulation, and (ii) multi-spectral axilens-based focusing devices that achieve simultaneous focusing of radiation over selected spectral bands. The goals will be accomplished by a comprehensive integration of rigorous Rayleigh-Sommerfeld diffraction theory, device-level Finite Element Method (FEM) numerical design, materials fabrication, and experimental characterization of optical devices with integrated imaging and spectroscopic functionalities across a wide spectral range. While using silicon (Si) and titanium dioxide (TiO2) transparent dielectrics for the visible and near-infrared (NIR) spectral range, the research concepts, methods and design approach can naturally be extended to any wavelength of interest and dielectric materials platforms. The intellectual merit of the proposed research program relies on the development of novel and more powerful avenues for cost-effective, miniaturized, phase-engineered devices that are polarization insensitive, work over a large range of incidence angles, and combine highly-efficient focusing and grating responses that, in addition to optical spectroscopy, also find applications to multi- spectral optical detection, quantum information sources, and on-chip sensing. This project enables a substantial broader impact as it provides the foundation for the next generation of ultra-compact spectroscopic phase-modulated devices for optical imaging, sensing, and spectroscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this research program was to design and engineer novel Si-compatible, ultra-compact (< 50 µm2 footprint area), and scalable optical elements for light focusing, multi-spectral imaging, and spectroscopy that can solve the long-lasting problems of high-density integration of imaging, processing, and computing planar systems on a silicon chip, with applications ranging from optical communication, to high-resolution medical imaging, multi-spectral optical sensing, and on-chip quantum technology.

We achieved our goals by combining favorable aspects from diffractive optical elements with computational imaging and artificial neural networks techniques in order to design, fabricate, and experimentally characterize ultra-compact focusing devices that independently operate over multiple spectral bands in the visible range using transparent materials with large refractive index.

The major outcomes of our project in relation to its intellectual merit consisted in the demonstrations of engineered multi-focal and multi-band optical lenses and ultra-compact focusing micro-spectrometers based on designed optical phase in diffractive dielectric materials. Specifically, by leveraging optical neural networks and rigorous optimization techniques, we inversely designed and demonstrated novel spectroscopic devices that achieve simultaneous focusing of radiation over separated spectral bands with designed spatial/spectral bandwidths and spectral resolution. Specifically, (i) we achieved control of the spectral bandwidths at separate focal positions beyond the theoretical limit of single-lens devices with the same aperture size; (ii) demonstrated two-layer diffractive micro-lenses with designed focal spots at desired wavelengths; (iii) engineered novel focusing micro-spectrometers with nanometer-range spectral resolution, large focusing efficiency and numerical aperture, small footprint area < 50µm2, significantly improving the state-of-the-art of multifunctional phase-modulated optical devices.

Major outcomes were also the introduction of lens-less diffractive imaging systems by inverse design of micro-devices that exploit the isotropic scattering properties of certain disordered structures called hyperuniform phase plates (HPPs). These novel systems  have been successfully fabricated in high-transparency hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) and integrated within a commercial camera in a scalable fashion in order to demonstrate high-quality image reconstruction of real targets experimentally. Furthermore, based on the fruitful combination of electromagnetic scattering theory for dielectric nanoparticles and rigorous optimization theory, we introduced a novel and scalable approach based on functionalized focusing and spectroscopic units called “photonic patches”, which consist of small-scale arrays (~10 µm in size) of dielectric nanocylinders with optimal radii and positions obtained by gradient-based optimization techniques (i.e., rigorous adjoint optimization). We demonstrated that photonic patches achieve a number of imaging and spectroscopic functions in planar ultra-compact geometries without the need of multi-step lithography. Finally, we conceived and demonstrated novel types of miniaturized spectrometers based on the correlations of speckled electromagnetic fields scattered by planar devices with tailored (multifractal) disorder and reported a 4X throughput enhancement compared to traditional speckle spectrometers based on uncorrelated (i.e., non-fractal) disorder.

It is anticipated that the results demonstrated in this project will open practical and powerful new avenues for the integration of compact imaging and spectroscopic planar devices on the chip scale, with applications to optical communications, computing, imaging, spectroscopy, and the emerging field of quantum technology.

In the context of the Broader Impact of this proposal, our findings have established novel, Si-compatible diffractive devices with complete control of the spatial and spectral bandwidths across the visible wavelength range. This ability lays the foundation for the next generation of highly integrated, low-loss, cost-effective imaging and spectroscopic systems with micrometer sizes for numerous applications to information processing, multispectral sensing and  spectroscopy on the silicon chip.

Overall, three graduate students at Boston University contributed to the research and were supported at different stages by this program gaining substantial experience on materials science growth, fabrication, electromagnetic scattering theory, advanced modeling techniques, and device characterization. Their research led them to successfully defend their PhD work in the context of this research. Two of these PhD students won prestigious best dissertation awards in the respective Departments at Boston University. In addition, several undergraduate students at Boston University were involved across the different phases of the research and gained fundamental experience in optical imaging devices and techniques. The educational activities offered by this project were numerous and integrated graduate and undergraduate students at Boston University. The novel ideas and results from the research were incorporated into three graduate level courses at Boston University, (EC562 Fourier Optics, EC585 Quantum Engineering and Technology, and EC777 Nano and Quantum Optics). In addition, in partnership with the Boston University Photonics Center, the PI of this project organized and chaired an international symposium on “Photonics & Artificial Intelligence” that provided a stimulating, one-day forum for scientific talks and discussions, primarily intended for an audience of graduate students, in which the results of this research were broadly disseminated.

Finally, the main outcomes of this research have also been largely disseminated via peer-reviewed journal publications, conference presentations, and the organization of topical journal issues in partnership with OPTICA and Wiley publishers.
